        <div data-widget-def="ux3-general-image" data-widget-id="46f843f5-8f3d-4902-a5fd-4ceebad40356" class="logo">
        



        
        <img id="" alt="ACM Digital Library" src="/specs/products/acm/releasedAssets/images/acm-logo-dl-8437178134fce530bc785276fc316cbf.png" loading="eager">

        </div>
    

</div>
</div><div class="col-lg-9 col-md-8 col-sm-7 sticko__side-content">



        
        <div data-widgetid="f51662a0-fd51-4938-ac5d-969f0bca0843" class="table-of-content-wrapper"><div class="table-of-content table-of-content--lazy"><div data-accordion-vport="screen-sm" data-accordion-option="with-arrow" data-default-collapsed="false"><div class="accordion"><div class="accordion-tabbed rlist"><a href="#tableOfContent" class="sr-only-focusable">Skip Abstract Section</a><div class="toc__section accordion-tabbed__tab js--open" id="absSection"><a role="button" class="left-bordered-title section__title accordion-tabbed__control" id="secAbs" tabindex="0" aria-expanded="true">Abstract</a><div class="accordion-tabbed__content issue-abstract"><div class="abstractSection">
		<p>It is with great enthusiasm that we, on behalf of the Organizing Committee, invite you to join us for the 31st ACM SIGSAC Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS), a premier security and privacy conference where researchers, practitioners, and educators come together to present, learn, and debate research, innovation, and trends in the field of Computer and Communications Security and Privacy.</p> <p>This year, we are proud to introduce our conference theme to be "Inclusion, Mentorship, Community." These three pillars reflect our collective commitment to fostering a vibrant, supportive, and forwardthinking environment within the CCS community. Particularly, we host our inaugural Doctoral Symposium, which offers PhD students a unique platform to receive timely, constructive feedback on their dissertation research from leading experts in our community. Additionally, our first-ever Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) Workshop is designed to cultivate a culture that embraces diversity and champions equity in our field. Moreover, understanding the importance of guidance and support, we have organized panels focusing on Student Mentoring, Faculty Mentoring, and Public Service. These panels are designed to facilitate mentorship connections, share valuable experiences, and encourage service that extends the impact of our work beyond academia. These new initiatives are also opportunities to strengthen the bonds within our CCS community.</p> <p>Regarding the main conference, this year's main conference is our largest ever, featuring 328 paper presentations that showcase the latest research and developments in our field. We are also honored to have two distinguished keynote speakers: Dr. Dan Boneh and Dr. Gene Tsudik, who will share their invaluable insights and perspectives on pressing topics in security and privacy. Additionally, 18 specialized workshops will take place on the pre-conference and post-conference days, providing platforms for focused discussions and collaborations on numerous specialized topics.</p>

class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690200">Camel: Communication-Efficient and Maliciously Secure Federated rapidly become a compelling paradigm that enables multiple clients to jointly train a model by sharing only gradient updates for aggregation, without revealing their local private data. class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3670386">Inbox Invasion: Exploiting MIME Ambiguities to Evade Email Attachment Detectors</a></h5><ul class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690277">Characterizing Ethereum Address Poisoning Attack</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" style="height: auto;"><li><a href="/profile/99661084445" title="Shixuan Guan"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author Picture" aria-hidden="true"><span>Shixuan Guan</span></a><span>,</span></li><li><a href="/profile/99661079274" title="Kai Li"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author Picture" aria-hidden="true"><span>Kai Li</span></a></li></ul><div class="issue-item__detail"><span>Pages 986â€“1000</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690277" class="issue-item__doi dot-separator">https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690277</a></span></div><div class="issue-item__abstract truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>This paper presents the first comprehensive analysis of the address poisoning attack surged on the Ethereum blockchain. class="issue-item__detail"><span>Pages 1121â€“1135</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690203" class="issue-item__doi class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690310">Top of the Heap: Efficient Memory Error Protection of Safe Heap Objects</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" id="authorsListId-os1h" aria-labelledby="authorList-or2g" style="height: auto;"><li><a major source of software vulnerabilities. open-access">Open Access</div></div><div class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690233">Faster FHE-Based Single-Server Private Information Retrieval</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" style="height: auto;"><li><a href="/profile/99661436013" truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>This work introduces KsPIR, a new practically efficient single-server private information retrieval (PIR) system that outperforms the state-of-the-art Spiral (Menon and Wu, S&amp;P 2022) in terms of server<span class="read-more" aria-expanded="false" role="button" tabindex="0"> <span class="ellipsis">â€¦</span> (More) <i class=" class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690349">Actively Secure Private Set Intersection in the Client-Server Setting</a></h5><ul Sun</span></a><span>,</span></li><li><a href="/profile/81100411790" title="Jonathan Katz"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author <p>Private set intersection (PSI) allows two parties to compute the intersection of their sets without revealing anything else. In some applications of PSI, a server holds a large set and runs a PSI protocol with<span class="read-more" aria-expanded="false" role="button" tabindex="0"> <span class="ellipsis">â€¦</span> (More) class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3670374">Provable Security for PKI Schemes</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" id="authorsListId-41jk" aria-labelledby="authorList-ac9j" style="height: auto;"><li><a href="/profile/99660086254" title="Sara WrÃ³tniak"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author Picture" aria-hidden="true"><span>Sara WrÃ³tniak</span></a><span>,</span></li><li><a href="/profile/99659201643" title="Hemi Leibowitz"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670374" class="issue-item__doi dot-separator">https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670374</a></span></div><div class="issue-item__abstract truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>PKI schemes provide a critical foundation for applied cryptographic protocols. However, there are no rigorous security specifications for realistic PKI schemes, and therefore, no PKI schemes were proven secure.<span class="read-more" aria-expanded="false" role="button" tabindex="0"> <span class="ellipsis">â€¦</span> (More) <i class=" icon-section_arrow_d "></i></span></p></div><div class="issue-item__footer clearfix"><div class="issue-item__footer-wrapper class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690225">Almost Instance-optimal Clipping for Summation Problems in the Shuffle Model of Differential class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690238">ProFake: Detecting Deepfakes in the Wild against Quality Degradation with Progressive Quality-adaptive Learning</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" id="authorsListId-u0kq" advances in deepfake detection on current datasets, detecting visual deepfakes in real-world scenarios (e.g., deepfake videos and live streaming on YouTube) remains a challenge<span class="read-more" class="issue-item__detail"><span>Pages 3065â€“3079</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670379" class="issue-item__doi dot-separator">https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670379</a></span></div><div class="issue-item__abstract truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>Threshold secret sharing enables distributing a message to <em>n</em> parties such that no subset of fewer than <em>t</em> parties can learn the message, whereas any subset of at least <em>t</em> parties can recover the message. Despite<span class="read-more" aria-expanded="false" role="button" tabindex="0"> <span class="ellipsis">â€¦</span> (More) <i class=" icon-section_arrow_d "></i></span></p></div><div open-access">Open Access</div></div><div class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690351">Real-World Universal zkSNARKs are Non-Malleable</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" style="height: auto;"><li><a href="/profile/99659042075" title="Antonio 3138â€“3151</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690351" class="issue-item__doi dot-separator">https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690351</a></span></div><div class="issue-item__abstract truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>Simulation extractability is a strong security notion of zkSNARKs that guarantees that an attacker who produces a valid proof must know the corresponding witness, even if the attacker had prior access<span class="read-more" aria-expanded="false" role="button" tabindex="0"> <span class="ellipsis">â€¦</span> (More) <i class=" href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3670289">Arke: Scalable and Byzantine Fault Tolerant Privacy-Preserving Contact Discovery</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" existing membership inference attacks (MIAs) utilize metrics (e.g., loss) calculated on the model's final state, while recent advanced attacks leverage metrics computed at various stages, including href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690377">Scalable Equi-Join Queries over Encrypted Database</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" with Rational Parties</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" id="authorsListId-200h" aria-labelledby="authorList-x3jl" style="height: href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3670356">Batching-Efficient RAM using Updatable Lookup Arguments</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>Trusted execution environments (TEEs) are widely employed to protect deep neural networks (DNNs) from untrusted hosts (e.g., hypervisors). class="issue-heading">research-article</div></div><div class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690250">Fisher in recent years suggest that an adversary can compromise the integrity of a deep neural network (DNN) by manipulating a small set of training samples. height="24"></a></div></div></div><div class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3670355">Practical Non-interactive Encrypted Conjunctive Search with Leakage Suppression</a></h5><ul class="rlist--inline loa truncate-list trunc-done" aria-label="authors" data-lines="1" id="authorsListId-hj8y" aria-labelledby="authorList-53m8" style="height: auto;"><li><a href="/profile/99660813294" title="Yunling Wang"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author Picture" aria-hidden="true"><span>Yunling Wang</span></a><span>,</span></li><li><a href="/profile/99658990598" title="Shi-Feng Sun"><img class="author-picture" src="/pb-assets/icons/DOs/default-profile.svg" width="24" height="24" alt="Author Picture" aria-hidden="true"><span>Shi-Feng Sun</span></a><span>,</span></li><li class="count-list"><button class="removed-items-count" id="authorList-53m8" aria-controls="authorsListId-hj8y" aria-expanded="false" aria-label="View other 4 authors"> + 4 </button></li></ul><div class="issue-item__detail"><span>Pages 4658â€“4672</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670355" class="issue-item__doi dot-separator">https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3670355</a></span></div><div class="issue-item__abstract truncate-text trunc-done" data-lines="4" style="height: auto;"> <p>Encrypted conjunctive search enables server to perform efficient conjunctive query over encrypted data while guaranteeing data and query privacy. class="issue-item__content"><div class="issue-item__content-right"><h5 class="issue-item__title"><a href="/doi/10.1145/3658644.3690865">Securing Cyber-Physical Systems via Advanced Cyber Threat aria-hidden="true"><span>EfrÃ©n LÃ³pez-Morales</span></a></li></ul><div class="issue-item__detail"><span>Pages 5119â€“5121</span><span><a href="https://doi.org/10.1145/3658644.3690865"     <li><a href="/journals" title="Browse a listing of ACMâ€™s Journals">Journals</a></li>
